repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
fixes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536
todo:
- [x] docs
- [ ] update examples in docs
- [x] news.txt
- [x] tests

comment_data.body:
After some more thought, let's make it like this:

```suggestion
vim.keymap.set({mode}, {opts}, {lhs}, {rhs})                *vim.keymap.set()*
```

that should resolve the objections?

I don't think it does resolve the objections. I think people are happy with the current signature and `opts` at the end works the best for most people. Putting it anywhere else is at best a sideways change, and at worst a regression for a lot of mappings.

If you _really_ want to put `rhs` at the end then the only option I see is:

```
vim.keymap.set({mode}, [{opts},] {lhs}, {rhs})
```

So `opts` is optional.

But I'm sure this will bring other objections.

> If you _really_ want to put `rhs` at the end then the only option I see is:

that's exactly the idea. overloads are normal and cheap, if anyone objects to this they are a bot.

comment_regular_data.body:
@justinmk since you originally proposed this
should I encourage users in the docs to use the new format when they use a callback (just add examples like this and remove old ones)?

Please mark as Draft until this is ready.

The code looks a bit more "busy" than I expected, is there a way to simplify it?

> should I encourage users in the docs to use the new format when they use a callback (just add examples like this and remove old ones)?

Don't need to "encourage", but I do think we should update all examples to use the function-last form.

There are a lot of downvotes on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536 , but I assume they are addressed by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536#issuecomment-2081528222 which has upvotes.

> There are a lot of downvotes on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536 , but I assume they are addressed by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536#issuecomment-2081528222 which has upvotes.

Well I personally also don't really like adding this (even though deprecating the old format would have been even worse)
but I don't know how other people think about this. Just opened this pr to see how complicated it would be to implement and also discuss it again

> Well I personally also don't really like adding this

why? It seems unintuitive that RHS ("right hand side") is not the right-most arg. `opts` are just parameters, why are they separated from the left most parameters? The main part of every mapping is its actual definition, placing that in the middle of the args seems completely random.

And by making this an overload (which seems pretty natural and would be a common approach in any language that supports overloads), there is no cost.

things to discuss
which one should be the `@overload`? because the docs are generated form the other annotations so this will be the one the function signature in the docs is based on and will also determine the parameter order

And do we want to support both string and function rhs as last argument? If we don't it gets really confusing but the developer guideline is just about callbacks and `vim.keymap.set("i", "asdf", nil, "<esc>")` is just ugly

> which one should be the `@overload`? 

the legacy signature

> And do we want to support both string and function rhs as last argument? If we don't it gets really confusing

sure

> why?

the majority of the api functions have `opts` as their last argument (don't know if any `vim.api.*` function doesn't and also e.g. `vim.fs.*` do)

I think the `callback` last argument isn't strong enough here
in the docs it says
>- Any function signature that accepts a callback function should define the
  callback as the LAST parameter, if possible. This improves readability of
  calls by placing the less "noisy" arguments near the start. >
    GOOD:
    filter(table, opts, function() … end)
    BAD:
    filter(function() … end, table, opts)

imo the big difference here and there is that the callback there is obviously bad because the thing it operates on is after it
here I think the readability is better as it is now
the `opts` table has many different options which are less important to see what the thing does. They just "modify" the action (e.g. expr or buffer). The table can also be quite big and be way more noisy than a callback like `vim.lsp.buf.references`. You must also consider that often the callback is just a function like in the example I just gave (without `function() ... end`) or just a string (also regarding https://github.com/nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices where people are encouraged to use `<Plug>` mappings)
that would result in not really readable function signatures like `vim.keymap.set("n","gc",{buffer=true,desc="Toggle comment on current line"}, "<Plug>CommentToggleLine"
Also I personally really don't like `nil` arguments if a user doesn't want any opts even though that's never "required" because it's an overload it's kinda confusing having two different signatures

last but not least
the `vim.api.nvim_set_keymap` function and also the old vimscript mappings always have `lhs` and `rhs` right next to each other and after each others and users are used to this

> the majority of the api functions have `opts` as their last argument

That is simply a limitation of the API, which does not support variable "arity" of function signatures.

> The table can also be quite big and be way more noisy

All kinds of things are possible. Speculating about this makes it impossible to predict anything as a user, so it's better to have a consistent guideline. Options can be verbose sometimes, but the function is *always* present.

> the `vim.api.nvim_set_keymap` function 

API is a low-level extension point for exposing internals. It's irrelevant for Lua which is a high-level interface intended to be maximally ergonomic.

> and also the old vimscript mappings always have `lhs` and `rhs` right next to each other and after each others and users are used to this

The vimscript mappings provide all "options" before the RHS. If we want to match that, the signature would be:

    set(..., lhs, rhs)

~~But I don't think that's necessary, because as a function call, LHS is visually what one looks for, so it's useful for it to be near the start.~~ 

Edit: I think it makes sense for LHS, RHS to be next to each other, so the signature is:

    set(mode, opts, lhs, rhs)

> That is simply a limitation of the API, which does not support variable "arity" of function signatures

> API is a low-level extension point for exposing internals. It's irrelevant for Lua which is a high-level interface intended to be maximally ergonomic.

ik but it's also used a lot in lua code and therefor people are used to having `opts` last

>  LHS is visually what one looks for, so it's useful for it to be near the start.

but people also look for the rhs and it also should be there imo
that's what the rest of my comment was about

> ..., but I do think we should update all examples to use the function-last form.

> the legacy signature

The current signature is better IMO, it shouldn't become legacy.

> There are a lot of downvotes on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536 , but I assume they are addressed by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28536#issuecomment-2081528222 which has upvotes.

I think people are ok with adding an _alternative_ where opts are in the middle, and that is the overload (as #28536 specifies).

I think people dislike this change because it really doesn't solve any problems. The motivation seems to be to just unnecessarily apply the _guildeline_ (not rule) of function as the last argument. And note `rhs` is often not a function. As an example, in my [config](https://github.com/lewis6991/dotfiles/blob/91402eeb8b870f72f22468d4c23654c175b048c7/config/nvim/lua/lewis6991/init.lua#L143-L252), about 50% of my mappings use a string, 50% use opts, and less than 10% use an anonymous function, so this new signature wouldn't improve anything.

@justinmk it seems like most people (including myself) agree with lewis statement

is this enough reason for you to close this pr and the related issue as won't fix?

continued in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30511

I dropped the "lhs can be a list" idea since it's probably not worth the complexity.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(lua): add new overload to vim.keymap.set
